Article: MADISON, Wis. â Sure, autonomous vehicles can run safely on public roads without a driver â mostly. The operative word here is âmostly.â Itâs time that both AI developers and the tech-gullible media ceased to marvel over the incredibly fast, powerful processors and advancements of sensor technologies. Yes, science has advanced. The bigger questions to ask are how we can be sure that robocar sensors are giving out accurate perception information, whether we can explain the decisions made by AI, and â most importantly â how we validate the safety of autonomous driving. Intel/Mobileye held a media event in Jerusalem last Thursday, offering a group of reporters a taste of travel inside Mobileyeâs autonomous vehicle equipped with 12 cameras but no other sensors. The company is testing 35 AVs currently available âin inventoryâ out of some 100 vehicles that Intel previously promised to build before the end of this year. (Photo: Intel)  The media event gave Intel/Mobileye an opportunity to show how far its team has advanced in AV development and to publicly explain a car safety concept called âthe Responsibility-Sensitive Safety (RSS) model.â The goal, of course, is AVs that behave responsibly on public roads. Industry observers applauded Mobileyeâs willingness to discuss its AV strategy. However, this demo opened the door to a host of issues that the AV industry, from Waymo to Intel/Mobileye, has yet to explore, examine, and test before L4 and L5 vehicles can hit the road without hitting something else. Issues include how to achieve âtrue redundancyâ in perception, how to explain objectively what âsafeâ really means, and how to formulate âa consistent and complete set of safety rulesâ agreeable to the whole AV industry, according to Phil Koopman, professor of Carnegie Mellon University. Separately, the public AV demo in Jerusalem inadvertently allowed a local TV stationâs video camera to capture Mobileyeâs car running a red light. (Fast-forward the video to 4:28 for said scene.) According to Mobileye, the incident was not a software bug in the car. Instead, it was triggered by electromagnetic interference (EMI) between a wireless camera used by the TV crew and the traffic lightâs wireless transponder. Mobileye had equipped the traffic light with a wireless transponder â for extra safety â on the route that the AV was scheduled to drive in the demo. As a result, crossed signals from the two wireless sources befuddled the car. The AV actually slowed down at the sight of a red light, but then zipped on through. While Mobileye isnât blaming the TV crew for this blunder, itâs a reminder that the industry is still in the experimental stage. Computer vision-only approach for now  For months, technology companies, tier ones, and OEMs have been talking about âsensor fusionâ â combining different sensor technologies â to help AVs figure out unexpected objects in the road. While practically everyone regards sensor fusion as a given, the industry is nowhere close to a methodology to validate whether perception information generated by each sensor is accurate, let alone whether information from multiple sensors can correctly fuse without any software glitches. The decision made by Mobileye to test its AV fleet powered only by cameras demonstrates its conviction that it must validate â first and foremost â âa comprehensive end-to-end solution from processing only the camera data.â  Amnon Shashua
